answers: The group discussed recognition results generated for 20 minutes of close-talking microphone data. Recognition performance was very good, indicating promising results for forced alignment procedures and the ability to analyze other important signal information, e.g. prosody and overlapping speech. It was decided that close-talking data should be downsampled and fed to the SRI recognizer to compare recognition performance, and that data from the far-field microphones should be tested on the recognizer as soon as possible. The group also discussed recording setup and equipment issues.

pred:
We still have seven-day-a-week crisis care. We've made clear that we're not going to step back on mental health services, including those for children and young people. We've also been looking at how we provide the service in a different way.

Query: How much do we understand about how this virus impacts children and young people, and their role in transmitting the virus? And how important is it that this is considered in the Welsh Government's exit strategy, especially in the context of reopening schools?
Answer: Our understanding is developing about the virus and its impact on children and young people. It's still the case that children and young people are less likely to be affected significantly by COVID-19 than people with a range of healthcare conditions. Part of the honest challenge is that we don't fully understand the impact on the mental health and well-being of children and young people, but we do expect there will have been an impact. We're working with both health boards and our own knowledge and analytical services across the Government to both try to further understand what that is and the difference that has been made. Until we have more contact with families, we may not fully understand that.

Query: What assessment has the Welsh Government made of the impact on the coronavirus pandemic on health and social services as they relate to children and young people in Wales?
Answer: We have made clear that we are concerned about the direct physical and mental health impact of lockdown restrictions. You don't need to be a parent to recognise that that's a potential issue for children and young people. But the bigger challenge is about the pause or the interruption in work to create the in-patient capacity that I've previously committed to. So, I want to understand what that really means, but again I'm really impressed by the continuing commitment of our staff to deliver this service for children and young people.

Query: How has the Welsh Government been monitoring the impact of coronavirus on health and social services as they relate to children and young people in Wales?
Answer: We are having weekly meetings with the heads of children's services, and we are also capturing the critical data in terms of the way that they've been operating. So, that will assist us in our monitoring arrangements going forward.

pred: The meeting was about the details of a project to develop a system that can help people understand the intentions of others in the context of a tourist guide.
answers: The meeting was about a computer based navigation system that will be used to conduct linguistic experiments on navigational terminology and intentionality, and it was simultaneously being recorded for another project. The navigational interface allows people to walk around a place and perform basic actions, like entering a building. Its goal is to understand what people intend to do based on granular linguistic features. The experimental set up is that people talk to a human assistant who controls the program in an attempt to complete a certain task. To study intentionality, the team will determine important linguistic features and use a Bayes model to see if they can predict the intention based on utterances.

# Children, Young People and Education Committee - 12 May 2020

The Children, Young People and Education Committee is meeting.

The meeting is bilingual, with simultaneous translation available.

You can join the meeting as an observer and see questions and answers as they happen.


The next item is questions to the Minister for Education. We'll move straight on to that.

Questions to the Minister for Education

Lynne Neagle AM: Good afternoon. I'm very pleased to welcome the Minister for Education, Kirsty Williams, to the meeting. I'm also pleased to welcome her officials, Rhys Parry, deputy director general, and Rhys Davies, head of the coronavirus task and finish group. Minister, can you tell us what the task and finish group has been doing since it was established?
Kirsty Williams AM: The task and finish group has been meeting weekly to consider the issues around the reopening of schools.
